children.value: Advection phenomena are characterized by the transport of information at finite speed. This implies that the solution at a given point in space and time can be affected only by the initial data in a limited region of space. For now, we continue to ignore the effects of boundaries.

children.value: We now state an important principle about a necessary relationship between domains of dependence.
In order for a numerical method for an evolutionary equation to converge to the correct solution, the numerical domain of dependence in the limit

children.html: h→0,h \to 0,h→0,
τ→0\tau\to 0τ→0

children.value: must contain the exact domain of dependence.
Although we will not provide the rigor behind this theorem, its conclusion is not difficult to justify. If the CFL condition does not hold, the exact solution at

children.html: (x,t)(x,t)(x,t)

children.value: could be affected by a change in the initial data while having no effect on the numerical solution. Hence there is no way for the method to get the solution correct for all problems. By contradiction, then, the CFL criterion is necessary for convergence.

children.value: is the speed at which information moves in the numerical method, which leads to the following restatement.
The CFL condition requires that the maximum propagation speed in the numerical method be at least as large as the maximum speed in the original
to imply a necessary time step restriction

children.html: τ≤h/∣c∣\tau \le h/|c|τ≤h/∣c∣

children.value: . This restriction for advection is much less severe than the

children.html: τ=O(h2)\tau = O(h^2)τ=O(h2)

children.value: restriction we derived for Euler in the heat equation in
. This is our first clear indication that advection is less stiff than diffusion.
We solve linear advection with velocity

children.html: c=2c=2c=2

children.value: and periodic end conditions. The initial condition is numerically, though not mathematically, periodic.
For time stepping, we use the adaptive explicit method

using OrdinaryDiffEq
m = 400;
x, Dₓ = FNC.diffper(m, [0, 1])
u_init = x -> exp( -80 * (x - 0.5)^2 )
ode = (u, c, t) -> -c * (Dₓ*u)
IVP = ODEProblem(ode, u_init.(x), (0., 2.), 2.)
u = solve(IVP, RK4());

using Plots
t = range(0, 2, 81);
U = reduce(hcat, u(t) for t in t)
contour(x, t, U'; 
    color=:redsblues,  clims=(-1, 1),
    xaxis=(L"x"),  yaxis=(L"t"),
    title="Linear advection",  right_margin=3Plots.mm)
In the space-time plot above, you can see the initial hump traveling rightward at constant speed. It fully traverses the domain once for each integer multiple of

children.value: ), then the CFL condition suggests that the time step should be cut by a factor of 2 also.

x, Dₓ = FNC.diffper(m, [0, 1])
IVP = ODEProblem(ode, u_init.(x), (0., 2.), 2.)
u = solve(IVP, RK4())
println("Number of time steps for m = 800: $(length(u.t))")

The advection equation allows information to propagate in only one direction. This asymmetry can have important repercussions.
If the domain of dependence at

children.html: (x,t)(x,t)(x,t)

children.value: always lies to one side of

children.html: xxx

children.value: , and the other direction is called the
Numerical methods can also have a directional preference.

children.html: ut+cux=0u_t+cu_x=0ut​+cux​=0

children.label: cflbackward
children.html: ux(xi,tj)≈Ui,j−Ui−1,jh u_x(x_i,t_j) \approx \frac{U_{i,j}-U_{i-1,j}}{h}ux​(xi​,tj​)≈hUi,j​−Ui−1,j​​

children.value: together with an Euler scheme in time. It should be clear that

children.html: Ui,jU_{i,j}Ui,j​

children.value: depends only on points to the left of

children.html: xix_ixi​

children.value: , i.e., the upwind direction of the numerical method is to the left. But if

children.html: c<0c<0c<0

children.value: is to the right. Hence, it is impossible to satisfy the CFL condition under these choices.

children.label: cflforward
children.html: ux(xi,tj)≈Ui+1,j−Ui,jh u_x(x_i,t_j) \approx \frac{U_{i+1,j}-U_{i,j}}{h}ux​(xi​,tj​)≈hUi+1,j​−Ui,j​​

children.value: with explicit time stepping leads to the inverse conclusion: its upwind direction is to the right, and it must fail if

children.html: c>0c>0c>0

children.value: is readily generalized: if the numerical method has an upwind direction, the CFL condition requires that it must agree with the upwind direction of the
and a numerical method have different upwinding directions, the method cannot converge to the exact solution.

It probably seems like one should always use a centered difference scheme, so that upwinding is not an issue. However, at a shock front, this requires differencing across a jump in the solution, which causes its own set of difficulties.
Now suppose that the linear advection equation is posed on a finite domain

children.html: x∈[a,b]x \in [a,b]x∈[a,b]

children.value: has only a first-order derivative in

children.html: xxx

children.value: , we should have only one boundary condition. But should it be specified at the left end, or at the right end?

Upwinding considerations provide the answer. If we impose a condition at the downwind side of the domain, there is no way for that boundary information to propagate into the interior of the domain as time advances. Conversely, at points close to the upwind boundary, the domain of dependence soon wants to move past the boundary, which is impossible, so there has to be information provided there.
with an upwind direction, the boundary condition must be specified at the inflow (i.e., upwind) end of the domain.

children.html: c>0c>0c>0

children.value: in the advection equation, the inflow is at the left end, and for

children.html: c<0c<0c<0

children.value: , it is at the right end.

children.html: [0,1][0,1][0,1]
c=−1c=-1c=−1

children.value: , the right boundary is in the upwind/inflow direction. Thus a well-posed boundary condition is

children.value:
m = 100
x, Dₓ = FNC.diffmat2(m, [0, 1])

interior = 1:m
extend = v -> [v; 0]

function ode!(f, v, c, t)
    u = extend(v)
    uₓ = Dₓ * u
    @. f = -c * uₓ[interior]
end;
Now we solve for an initial condition that has a single hump.

t = range(0, 0.75, 80)
U = reduce(hcat, extend(u(t)) for t in t)
contour(x, t, U';
    color=:blues,  clims=(0, 1), 
    xaxis=(L"x"),  yaxis=(L"t"),
    title="Advection with inflow BC")
We find that the hump gracefully exits out the downwind end.

anim = @animate for t in range(0, 1, 161) 
    plot(x, extend(u(t));
        label=@sprintf("t = %.4f", t), 
        xaxis=(L"x"),  yaxis=(L"u(x, t)", (0, 1)), 
        title="Advection equation with inflow BC",  dpi=150)
end
mp4(anim,"figures/advection-inflow.mp4")

children.html: u(1,t)=0u(1,t)=0u(1,t)=0

children.value: we were to try to impose the downwind condition

children.html: u(0,t)=0u(0,t)=0u(0,t)=0

children.value: , we only need to change the index of the interior nodes and where to append the zero value.

interior = 2:m+1
extend = v -> [0; v]

init = @. exp( -80*(x[interior] - 0.5)^2 )
ivp = ODEProblem(ode!, init, (0., 0.25), -1)
u = solve(ivp);

t = range(0, 0.2, 61)
U = reduce(hcat, extend(u(t)) for t in t)
contour(x, t, U'; 
    color=:redsblues,  clims=(-1, 1),
    xaxis=(L"x"),  yaxis=(L"t"), 
    title="Advection with outflow BC",  right_margin=3Plots.mm)
This time, the solution blows up as soon as the hump runs into the boundary because there are conflicting demands there.

anim = @animate for t in range(0, 0.2, 41) 
    plot(x, extend(u(t));
        label=@sprintf("t = %.4f", t),
        xaxis=(L"x"),  yaxis=(L"u(x,t)", (0, 1)), 
        title="Advection equation with outflow BC",  dpi=150)
end
mp4(anim,"figures/advection-outflow.mp4")

children.value:
m = 80
x, Dx, Dxx = FNC.diffmat2(m, [0, 1])

chop = lambda u : u[:-1]
extend = lambda v: hstack([v, 0])

ode = lambda t, v: -c * chop( Dx @ extend(v) )
c = -1
Now we solve for an initial condition that has a single hump.

u_init = exp(-80 * (x - 0.5) ** 2)
sol = solve_ivp(ode, (0, 1), chop(u_init), method="RK45", dense_output=True)
u = lambda t: extend(sol.sol(t))

t = linspace(0, 1, 80)
U = [u(tj) for tj in t]
contour(x, t, U, levels=arange(0.15, 1.0, 0.2))
xlabel("$x$"),  ylabel("$t$")
title("Advection with inflow BC");
We find that the hump gracefully exits out the downwind end.

from matplotlib import animation
fig, ax = subplots()
curve = ax.plot(x, u_init)[0]
time_text = ax.text(0.05, 0.9, '', transform=ax.transAxes)
ax.set_xlabel("$x$")
ax.set_ylabel("$u(x,t)$")
ax.set_ylim(-0.1, 1.1)
ax.set_title("Advection with inflow BC")

def snapshot(t):
    curve.set_ydata(u(t))
    time_text.set_text(f"t = {t:.2f}")

anim = animation.FuncAnimation(
    fig, snapshot, frames=linspace(0, 1, 101)
    )
anim.save("figures/advection-inflow.mp4", fps=30)
close()

chop = lambda u : u[1:]
extend = lambda v: hstack([0, v])

sol = solve_ivp(ode, (0, 1), chop(u_init), method="RK45", dense_output=True)
u = lambda t: extend(sol.sol(t))

U = [u(tj) for tj in t]
clf
contour(x, t, U, levels=arange(0.15, 1.0, 0.2))
xlabel("$x$"),  ylabel("$t$")
title("Outflow boundary condition");
This time, the solution blows up as soon as the hump runs into the boundary because there are conflicting demands there.

fig, ax = subplots()
curve = ax.plot(x, u_init)[0]
time_text = ax.text(0.05, 0.9, '', transform=ax.transAxes)
ax.set_xlabel("$x$")
ax.set_ylabel("$u(x,t)$")
ax.set_ylim(-0.1, 1.1)
ax.set_title("Advection with outflow BC")

anim = animation.FuncAnimation(
    fig, snapshot, frames=linspace(0, 0.5, 51)
    )
anim.save("figures/advection-outflow.mp4", fps=30)
close()
✍ Suppose you want to model the weather, including winds up to speed

km/hr, using an explicit method with a second-order centered spatial discretization. If the shortest time step you can take is 4 hr, what is the CFL limit on the spatial resolution of the model? Is this a lower bound or an upper bound?

✍ Suppose you want to model the traffic on a high-speed freeway using an explicit method with a second-order centered spatial discretization. Derive a CFL condition on the allowable time step, stating your assumptions carefully.
✍ For the heat equation, the domain of dependence at any
